channel.title: NASA Image of the Day
channel.description: The latest NASA "Image of the Day" image.

item.title: Snow and Sand in Central Asia
item.description: In December 2018, an astronaut on the International Space Station took this highly oblique photograph of snow on the eastern Tien Shan and Taklimakan Desert in Central Asia.

item.title: Cloud Formation in the South Indian Ocean
item.description: An astronaut aboard the International Space Station snapped this image as the station flew 265 miles above this cloudy formation in the south Indian Ocean.

item.title: Operation IceBridge: Exploring Alaska’s Mountain Glaciers
item.description: In Alaska, 5 percent of the land is covered by glaciers that are losing a lot of ice and contributing to sea level rise.

item.title: Nick Hague Completes 215th Spacewalk on Station
item.description: Astronaut Nick Hague performs a spacewalk on March 29, 2019.

item.title: Hubble Spots Flock of Cosmic Ducks
item.description: This star-studded image shows us a portion of Messier 11, an open star cluster in the southern constellation of Scutum (the Shield). Messier 11 is also known as the Wild Duck Cluster, as its brightest stars form a “V” shape that somewhat resembles a flock of ducks in flight.

item.title: Hubble Watches Spun-Up Asteroid Coming Apart
item.description: A small asteroid was caught in the process of spinning so fast it’s throwing off material, according to new data from NASA’s Hubble Space Telescope and other observatories.

item.title: Joan Stupik, Guidance and Control Engineer
item.description: When Joan Stupik was a child, her parents bought her a mini-planetarium that she could use to project the stars on her bedroom ceiling.

item.title: Orion Launch Abort System Attitude Control Motor Hot-Fire Test
item.description: A static hot-fire test of the Orion spacecraft's Launch Abort System Attitude Control Motor to help qualify the motor for human spaceflight, to help ensure Orion is ready from liftoff to splashdown for missions to the Moon.

item.title: Nick Hague Completes First Spacewalk
item.description: NASA astronaut Nick Hague completed the first spacewalk of his career on Friday, March 22, 2019. He and fellow astronaut Anne McClain worked on a set of battery upgrades for six hours and 39 minutes, on the International Space Station’s starboard truss.

item.title: Hubble Captures the Brilliant Heart of a Massive Galaxy
item.description: This fuzzy orb of light is a giant elliptical galaxy filled with an incredible 200 billion stars.

item.title: Margaret W. ‘Hap’ Brennecke: Trailblazer
item.description: Margaret W. ‘Hap’ Brennecke was the first female welding engineer to work in the Materials and Processes Laboratory at NASA’s Marshall Space Flight Center.

item.title: Waxing Gibbous Moon Above Earth's Limb
item.description: The waxing gibbous moon is pictured above Earth's limb as the International Space Station was orbiting 266 miles above the South Atlantic Ocean.

item.title: Preparing for Apollo 11
item.description: Apollo 11 backup crew members Fred Haise (left) and Jim Lovell prepare to enter the Lunar Module for an altitude test.

item.title: Going Where the Wind Takes It
item.description: ​Electronics technician Anna Noe makes final checks to the Doppler Aerosol Wind Lidar (DAWN) before it begins a cross-country road trip for use in an upcoming airborne science campaign.

item.title: Liftoff! A New Crew Heads to the Space Station
item.description: The Soyuz MS-12 spacecraft lifted off with Expedition 59 crewmembers on a journey to the International Space Station.

item.title: The Soyuz at Dawn
item.description: The Soyuz rocket is seen at dawn on launch site 1 of the Baikonur Cosmodrome, Thursday, March 14, 2019 in Baikonur, Kazakhstan.

item.title: Stephanie Wilson: Preparing for Space
item.description: Stephanie Wilson is a veteran of three spaceflights--STS-120, STS-121 and STS-131--and has logged more than 42 days in space.

item.title: Soyuz Rollout to the Launch Pad
item.description: The Soyuz rocket is transported by train to the launch pad, Tuesday, March 12, 2019 at the Baikonur Cosmodrome in Kazakhstan.

item.title: NASA's Future: From the Moon to Mars
item.description: NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine was photographed inside the Super Guppy aircraft that will carry the flight frame with the Orion crew module to a testing facility in Ohio.

item.title: Nancy Grace Roman: NASA's First Chief Astronomer
item.description: Nancy Grace Roman, NASA's first chief astronomer, is known as the 'Mother of Hubble.'

item.title: Ann R. McNair and Mary Jo Smith with Model of Pegasus Satellite, July 14, 1964
item.description: In 1964, Ann R. McNair and Mary Jo Smith pose with a model of a Pegasus Satellite.

item.title: NASA Captures Supersonic Shock Interaction
item.description: One of the greatest challenges of the fourth phase of Air-to-Air Background Oriented Schlieren flights, or AirBOS flight series was timing.

item.title: The Dawn of a New Era in Human Spaceflight
item.description: "The dawn of a new era in human spaceflight," wrote astronaut Anne McClain. McClain had an unparalleled view from orbit of SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft as it approached the International Space Station for docking on Sunday, March 3, 2019.

item.title: SpaceX Falcon 9 Rocket Lifts Off From Launch Complex 39A
item.description: On March 2, 2:49 a.m. EST, a two-stage SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket lifts off from Launch Complex 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida for Demo-1, the first uncrewed mission of the agency’s Commercial Crew Program.

item.title: SpaceX Demo-1 Launch
item.description: A SpaceX Falcon 9 rocket with the company's Crew Dragon spacecraft onboard launches from Launch Complex 39A, Saturday, March 2, 2019.

item.title: Mae Jemison, First African American Woman in Space
item.description: Mae Jemison was the first African Ameican woman in space.

item.title: SpaceX Demo-1: 'Go' for Launch
item.description: Two days remain until the planned liftoff of a SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft on the company’s Falcon 9 rocket—the first launch of a commercially built and operated American spacecraft and space system designed for humans.

item.title: Curiosity Drives Over a New Kind of Terrain
item.description: The Curiosity Mars Rover took this image with its Mast Camera (Mastcam) on Feb. 10, 2019 (Sol 2316).

item.title: Earnest C. Smith in the Astrionics Laboratory in 1964
item.description: Earnest C. Smith started at NASA Marshall in 1964 as an aerospace engineer in the Astrionics Laboratory. He was instrumental in the development and verification of the navigation system of the Lunar Roving Vehicle. Smith later became director of the Astrionics Laboratory at Marshall.

item.title: Alvin Drew Works on the International Space Station
item.description: NASA astronaut Alvin Drew participated in the STS-133 mission's first spacewalk.

item.title: Hubble Peers into the Vast Distance
item.description: This picture showcases a gravitational lensing system called SDSS J0928+2031.

item.title: Good Morning From the Space Station!
item.description: Good morning to our beautiful world, said astronaut Anne McClain from aboard the Space Station on Feb. 21, 2019.

item.title: Countdown to Calving at Antarctica's Brunt Ice Shelf
item.description: Cracks growing across Antarctica’s Brunt Ice Shelf are poised to release an iceberg with an area about twice the size of New York City. It is not yet clear how the remaining ice shelf will respond following the break, posing an uncertain future for scientific infrastructure and a human presence on the shelf that was first established in 1955.

item.title: Eat. Breathe. Do Science. Sleep Later.
item.description: Eat. Breathe. Do ccience. Sleep later. That's the motto of Derrick Pitts, NASA Solar System Ambassador.

item.title: NASA Glenn Keeps X-57 Cool
item.description: NASA is preparing to explore electric-powered flight with the X-57 Maxwell, a unique all-electric aircraft which features 14 propellers along its wing.

item.title: Astronauts Train for the Boeing Crew Flight Test
item.description: This preflight image from Feb. 6, 2019, shows NASA astronauts Mike Fincke and Nicole Mann and Boeing astronaut Chris Ferguson during spacewalk preparations and training inside the Space Station Airlock Mockup at NASA's Johnson Space Center in Houston.

item.title: Taking a Look Back at Opportunity's Record-Setting Mission
item.description: NASA's record-setting Opportunity rover mission on Mars comes to end.

item.title: Robert Curbeam: Building the Space Station, Making History
item.description: Robert Curbeam currently holds the record for the most spacewalks during a single spaceflight.

item.title: The Red Planet's Layered History
item.description: Erosion of the surface reveals several shades of light toned layers, likely sedimentary deposits, as shown in this image taken by the HiRISE camera on the Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter.

item.title: Mary Jackson: A Life of Service and a Love of Science
item.description: Mary Jackson began her engineering career in an era in which female engineers of any background were a rarity.

item.title: Vice President Attends NASA Day of Remembrance
item.description: Vice President Mike Pence visits the Space Shuttle Challenger Memorial after a wreath laying ceremony that was part of NASA's Day of Remembrance, Thursday, Feb. 7, 2019, at Arlington National Cemetery in Arlington, Va.

item.title: Apollo Astronaut Buzz Aldrin at the 2019 State of the Union
item.description: Astronaut Buzz Aldrin salutes after being introduced at the 2019 State of the Union address.

item.title: Star Formation in the Orion Nebula
item.description: The powerful wind from the newly formed star at the heart of the Orion Nebula is creating the bubble and preventing new stars from forming.

item.title: Victor Glover, One of the Crew of SpaceX's First Flight to Station
item.description: When SpaceX's Crew Dragon spacecraft lifts off on its first operational mission to the International Space Station, NASA astronaut Victor Glover will be aboard.

item.title: Sunrise From Columbia
item.description: On Jan. 22, 2003, the crew of Space Shuttle Columbia captured this sunrise from the crew cabin during Flight Day 7.

item.title: Hubble Accidentally Discovers a New Galaxy
item.description: Despite the vastness of space, objects tend to get in front of each other.

item.title: Sailing Over the Caribbean From the International Space Station
item.description: Portions of Cuba, the Bahamas and the Turks and Caicos Islands are viewed from the International Space Station.

item.title: Falcon 9, Crew Dragon Roll to Launch Pad
item.description: Falcon 9, Crew Dragon Roll to Launch Pad

item.title: Remembering Space Shuttle Challenger
item.description: NASA lost seven of its own on the morning of Jan. 28, 1986, when a booster engine failed, causing the Shuttle Challenger to break apart just 73 seconds after launch. In this photo from Jan. 9, 1986, the Challenger crew takes a break during countdown training at NASA's Kennedy Space Center.

item.title: Celebrating the 50th Anniversary of Apollo 8's Launch Into History
item.description: Fifty years ago on Dec. 21, 1968, Apollo 8 launched from Pad A, Launch Complex 39, Kennedy Space Center at 7:51 a.m. ES).

item.title: Station Crew Back on Earth After 197-Day Space Mission
item.description: Russian Search and Rescue teams arrive at the Soyuz MS-09 spacecraft shortly after it landed with Expedition 57 crew members.

item.title: SpaceX’s Crew Dragon Spacecraft and Falcon 9 Rocket
item.description: SpaceX’s Crew Dragon spacecraft and Falcon 9 rocket are positioned at the company’s hangar at Launch Complex 39A at NASA’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida, ahead of the test targeted for Jan. 17, 2019.

item.title: Testing the Space Launch System
item.description: Engineers built a tank identical to the Space Launch System tank that will be flown on Exploration Mission-1, the first flight of Space Launch System and the Orion spacecraft for testing.

item.title: 115 Years of Flight
item.description: For most of human history, we mortals have dreamed of taking to the skies. Then, 115 years ago on on December 17, 1903, Orville and Wilbur Wright achieved the impossbile.

item.title: Giant Black Hole Powers Cosmic Fountain
item.description: Before electricity, water fountains worked by relying on gravity to channel water from a higher elevation to a lower one. In space, awesome gaseous fountains have been discovered in the centers of galaxy clusters.

item.title: Astronauts Anne McClain and Serena Auñón-Chancellor Work Aboard the Station
item.description: NASA astronauts Anne McClain (background) and Serena Auñón-Chancellor are pictured inside the U.S. Destiny laboratory module aboard the International Space Station.

item.title: Spirit of Apollo - 50th Anniversary of Apollo 8 at the Washington National Cathedral
item.description: The Washington National Cathedral is seen lit up with space imagery prior to the Smithsonian National Air and Space Museum's Spirit of Apollo event commemorating the 50th anniversary of Apollo 8, Tuesday, Dec. 11, 2018 in Washington, DC.

item.title: ICESat-2 Reveals Profile of Ice Sheets
item.description: Less than three months into its mission, NASA’s Ice, Cloud and land Elevation Satellite-2, or ICESat-2, is already exceeding scientists’ expectations.

item.title: Viewing the Approach of SpaceX's Dragon to the Space Station
item.description: International Space Station Commander Alexander Gerst viewed SpaceX’s Dragon cargo craft chasing the orbital laboratory on Dec. 8, 2018 and took a series of photos.

item.title: Astronaut Anne McClain's First Voyage to the Space Station
item.description: "Putting this journey into words will not be easy, but I will try. I am finally where I was born to be," said astronaut Anne McClain of her first voyage to space.
